Key Arguments: The legislation limits freedom of speech and expression in the digital public space.
Definitions of 'misinformation', 'disinformation', and 'harm' are broad and open to interpretation.
The legislation does not clarify acceptable viewpoints or what constitutes 'misinformation'.
It creates a division in the community between those bound by misinformation rules and those who are exempt.
The definition of 'harm' is overly broad, including areas like health, environment, and the democratic process.
Decisions on misinformation will be made by private, unelected digital platforms.
Notable Quotes: The proposal will place limitations on freedom of speech and expression of ideas in the digital public space.
The terms and definitions of what constitutes ‘misinformation’, ‘disinformation’ and ‘harm’ in the legislation are extremely broad and open to a wide range of interpretations.
It will be incumbent on the digital platform to make the decisions on which comments, viewpoints and opinions constitute ‘misinformation’.
